text: As described previously [8] , 100 children 6-59 months old with malaria (positive Giemsa smear and T>37.5˚C) and hemoglobin 5.0-9.9 g/dL were enrolled in a randomized trial of iron therapy at Mulago Hospital in Kampala, Uganda (Fig 1) . Children were treated for malaria with parenteral artesunate and also given a 3-day course of oral artemether-lumefantrine. If children had a zinc protoporphyin (ZPP) concentration > = 80 μmol/mol heme, they were randomized either to begin a 27-day iron therapy regimen (2 mg/kg/day as liquid oral ferrous sulfate) concurrently with antimalarial treatment on Day 0 (immediate group, n = 50) or 28 days later on Day 28 (delayed group, n = 50). Children were given an insecticide-treated bednet and were followed for 56 days (Day 0 -Day 56).
